results.title: We can't stand still can we?
results.creator_credit: Ken McCready, Roman Bittman and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This film is about the urban renewal plan drawn up by the town council of High River, Alberta. It saved the town, and could save many others across Canada.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken McCready, Roman Bittman and ONF | NFB

results.title: We can't afford to be casual about child care (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Anne Smith, Michael Milan and Audio Visual Learning Centre, University of Otago
results.brief_description: Child care is discussed by Dr. Bettye Caldwell from the University of Arkansas and Pat Hubbard, director of the Dunedin community child care centre. They discuss whether child care damages mother-child attachment, the importance of an optimal environment for children in early years, the particular qualities and nature of good child care, and the difficulty in financing it

results.title: We call them killers
results.creator_credit: Tom Shandel, Peter Jones and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A rare opportunity to observe two killer whales, Haida and Chimo, kept at the time of filming at the Victoria Sealand of the Pacific Aquarium. Far from any show of ferocity, the huge mammals display a sense of fun and rapport with their trainers, especially during their performances for the public. Dr. Paul Spong, noted cetologist, describes his attempts at inter-species communication. Musician Paul Horn captivates Haida with the sounds of his flute.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Shandel, Peter Jones and ONF | NFB

results.title: We are one
results.brief_description:
A rhythmic montage-in-motion of children around the world - playing, running, dancing, crying, laughing, eating - with touching contrasts and funny similarities. The message is universal love and hope: modern skills give mankind the chance to make this one world.
Based on the NHK production by Akira Takasaka and Kuniji Kodama.

results.title: We all have our reasons
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth Stevens, Frances Reid and Iris Films
results.brief_description: We all have our reasons for drinking, yet seldom do we examine our reason. This film takes us into a group of women alcoholics whose sobriety ranges from one week to five years. We hear them talk about their experiences.

results.title: We've come a long way
results.creator_credit: John Halas, Anglo Iranian Oil Company and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: Illustrates a century of progress in the design of oil tankers dating from the time when oil casks were first lashed in the holds of cargo vessels. The film explains how the problems of dealing with escaping gas and of increasing the weight of cargo without imposing too great a strain on the hull of the tanker, were ultimately solved.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Halas, Anglo Iranian Oil Company and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films

results.title: We're gonna have recess (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Scott, William Canning and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: To smile at the antics of children in a playground is to smile at oneself. This is a candid camera view of the schoolyard during recess, when hearts are broken, scores settled, secrets told, and where a bouncing ball or a turning rope can still tell the future to a chanted rhyme. Filmed without commentary, this is a small world and a brief one, but a world of childhood that everyone will recognize. Film without words.

results.title: We'll show you what we're gonna do
results.brief_description: Shows the operation of an art program designed to teach eighteen blind, partially sighted, and additionally handicapped children. Suitable for tertiary/teacher level.

results.title: Wayward girls & wicked women. - Volume 3.
results.brief_description: This is the final part of a three volume series featuring the best of world animation by women. The three films included have been recognised for their ground breaking qualities and make witty and provocative use of the myths, fairytales, and sexual iconography that have affected the way women have been seen - and see themselves. Featuring: Asparagus/Susan Pitt; The Decision/Vera Neubauer; The Brooch Pin and the Sinful Clasp/Joanna Woodward.
